reviewText:
From all 4X games that I have played, Endless Space captures the feel of ruling over a galactic empire best.
My favorite element of the game is how solar systems work as a whole, and with every system consisting of different numbers and types of planets, with different anomalies and wonders, gives every system you colonize some kind of 'character'. I love getting immersed in the feeling of space exploration and being challenged by every new system. You have to ponder 'Should I colonize this system right now, or wait until I've researched more terraforming technologies? Should I specialize it as an industry system, or use it for economy and research? Is building this huge, expensive improvement worth it, or should I stick to the smaller improvements in this system?'.

The other side of this feeling is that the things you do in this game are at the macro-strategy level. You don't build single buildings on planets, you build improvements for the whole solar system. You don't manage single trade routes, you build trade improvements in systems, and the trade routes will automatically connect your systems with those of other civilizations you are at peace with, in the most profitable way. You don't tell every single ship in a battle where to move, you set fleet formations at the beginning of a battle, and choose general strategies (Things like 'weapon overclock', 'camouflage', 'sabotage', 'repair', and many more) and aiming patters ('spread fire', 'concentrate on one enemy' etc.) for each battle phase (Long-Range, Medium Range, Melee Range), and aside from that, can't influence the course of battle.

Many players criticize this, but I have the impression that this is part of the narrative, and implementing micro-management options would rather hurt the game flow. In this game, you are responsible for the grand strategies, and this is reflected in the mechanics.

Other elements of this game that are important for my recommendation, personally:
- All of the factions are interesting and have a ship style that fits them well
- The music, made by FlyByNo, is magnificent! It enhances the game greatly.
- The User Interface is amazingly clear and elegant. With 4X games generally being complicated, this makes Endless Space significantly more beginner-friendly and comfortable to play.

reviewText:
I am a huge fan of Masters of Orion 2.  I eagerly anticipated Masters of Orion 3, but it left me disappointed.  In many ways, Endless Space is what Masters of Orion 3 should have been.  The graphic are very visually appealing.  I sometimes find myself just gazing upon my planets when I zoom into a system because they are so pretty.  Another plus is that you manage your empire primarily at the system level, rather than the planetary level, so you don't get bogged down managing build queues for several dozen planets.  However, despite this system focus, each planet does offer unique contributions to your empire.  The game allows you to create customer races in a manner similar to MOO2.  You also have the ability to create customer starships, although not at the same level of detail as MOO2.

One of the games drawbacks is the combat.  You control combat at a very high strategic level, issuing just a few commands each round, and then twidding your thumbs and hoping for the best as the battle plays out in front of you.  There is a skill element to it, in that you have to try to pick a strategy that complements your fleet but also counters your opponent's strategy.  But often times this ends up feeling like a flashy game of rock/paper/scissors.

Another drawback is that the victory methods seem very mathmatical.  For example, you win a diplomatic victory by making deals throughout the game.  Each deal contributes to a percentage that adds up over time.  Once you reach 100%, you win.  To me, this makes victory feel anti-climactic.  I can't help comparing it to games like Civilization V or even Masters of Orion 2, where a diplomatic victory can become a very exciting effort to accumulate enough votes to win an election.

Ultimately, I would recommend this game, with two caveats.  1)  Unless you're super impatient, this game isn't so great that it's not worth waiting for a 50% or 75% off deal.  2)  If you are going to get it, buy it with the Disharmony expansion, which improves upon the base game a bit.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
It's an enjoyable 4X game.

The combat is a little bit dull, though. You send small fleets against other small fleets with really no input on the tactics, and the game gives you a cinematic sequence that shows your fleet in no formation whatsoever just shooting lasers and whatnot at enemies.

There's a quite enjoyable soundtrack in the background that reminds you that you're in space. The ingame menus are also well designed and the graphics are pleasant to look at.

The game might seem needlessly complicated in the first few hours, what with all the science stuff and silly abbreviations. The tutorial doesn't teach you very much, but you'll probably understand it after a few tries.

All in all, it's a rather enjoyable game. If you're a fan of 4X games such as Civilization or something then go on and try it out.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Endless Space is really only recommendable if you can see over a few bugs. Lots of GUI glitches, quirky fleet controls, odd AI behaviour, sometimes even resulting in situations that can only be resolved by starting a new game.
Behind the bugs, Endless Space is a solid turn-based strategy with an insane tech tree which not only has three zoom steps, but also a search box(!). It has a few base factions, each with their own design, but you can also create your own faction by picking an existing faction design. selecting an affinity, and picking perks to customise the game to your liking. Furthermore, the game is moddable, so with a bit of technical skill you can change the entire game around if you want.
If you can excuse a few bugs, Endless Space is definitely worth looking at if you enjoy space strategy.
Take a look at my screenshots for a few impressions.

reviewText:
I was incredibly surprised by this game. I had received it as a gift awhile back and from looking at gameplay videos on YouTube, I decided at the time it wasn't for me. I was dead wrong. This is my first 4X game (explore, expand, exploit, and exterminate) and have passed on other popular games like the Civilization series thinking that they would not be to my liking. Where should I start?

Graphically speaking, the game looks and performs very well. Are they top of the line, burn your motherboard-type graphics? No, but for what this game offers, I have been very pleased. As you can see from the pictures provided on this page, you'll spend most of your time looking at either the beautiful galaxy map or the various tabs located at the top left of your galaxy screen. Aside from staring at the galaxy map when zoomed out (which I particularly enjoy), the most eye candy you'll see in-game is of course the manual" fleet battles that I'm sure you'll encounter during play. I have my graphics set to the maximum settings and the frame rate runs easily above 100 per second. "Manual" fleet battles give you a visual representation of the battles as well as an opportunity to change your strategy as it progresses.

The tabs at the top of your screen consist of various actions you may queue up and/or perform on any turn. They range from your overall progression score compared to the other factions in the game to a comprehensive system list to manage your assets
hoursPlayed: diplomacy and finally your hero cards. These different tabs also range from useful to rather unnecessary. Later in the game (usually after 70 turns) I found myself using this tab the most so I could manage all of my systems happiness
voteText: tax rate
helpfulPercent: system improvements and resources and trade routes. The research tree is absolutely necessary to do anything in the game
votesHelpful: but what I found out to be more important was to skip reading guides online and simply just sit down for an hour and read through all of the different tiles. The fleet shipyard isn't required much as you simply just research new ship types in one of the four available tech trees in the research tab along with your various weapons
votesTotal: defenses and support modules in other trees and just make your own designs to build. The hero tab is rather ho-hum as quite simply you look to hire hero cards to place on a system or in a fleet. Managing your ability points as your level them up can be done elsewhere.\n\nDiplomacy on the other hand is somewhat frustrating. Split between a sort of good and evil with some rather in between
votesFunny: 10 factions in the base game offer a wide variety of gameplay. There are tiles that you upgrade diplomacy through your research tab to give you various bonuses
commentsCount: however what it won't take into account is that each faction responds differently to diplomacy. Some won't engage in it and are completely hostile
column16: others are hermits and avoid you almost altogether and others hate your guts if you're beating them economically like I have and take forever to form alliances and cooperative trade agreements. I don't quite like how it was designed and wished there was a little bit better way to draw up diplomatic relations more quickly and efficiently. If you're all for blowing them up and conquering systems
column17: then diplomacy won't even be an afterthought for you.\n\nPersonally
column18: diplomacy has been much to what I described. They tend to either be violent due to the inherited nature or they hold a grudge against you for being better than you for a good two-thirds of the game and then suddenly they become bootlickers and ask for the most ridiculous trades imaginable. Example: I was playing as a peaceful Amoeba faction
column19: exploring and expanding to three arms of an eight arm spiral galaxy with 5 other factions. One hated everyone and was suspicious of anyone (Cravers)
column20: one was constantly making threats and talking about glory and me being beneath them even though I was the master race for the whole game in terms of knowledge
column21: diplomatic
column22: expansive and economic power (Hissho); and the others kept to themselves and refused to talk to me until they decided I wasn't going anywhere (Pilgrams
column23: Amoeba and another Hissho). The first Hissho decided an alliance would be good
column24: but thought I was worthless and demanded I pay them a bunch of fuel resources to make the deal. reviewText:
This game... lets just say before the review starts, I recommend this game. It is worth the money.




Okay, the first time I played I played this game, was around the first time I started using steam. It was one of those free for the weekend deals. I tried it out. Its more than just the gameplay. Basically, one of the themes of this game (I personally feel) would have to be space. The music adds to that theme, the descriptive writing adds to it, the whole game gives off this awe inspiring mood to it. Not just it being epic, or cool, or relaxing. Whenever I play this, no matter how many times, I always feel like there is so much more to try to get at.
You are put on a random system in a randomly generated map type of your choosing. The other factions are also placed randomly. I can honestly say I have never gone through a game the same way twice. The ships are fully customizable except for their appearance.
When you play this game, it should come across your mind on how big the map is. You're not just in a solar system, you're in a galaxy. Your fleets are traveling to other systems, almost impossibly far away to imagine. The developers somewhat increased the size of the systems just so we can see these points. In reality, we wouldn't see anything from how far away the view is.
This game is awe-inspiring, fun, and overall a great game.

reviewText: Excellent 4X game. There are 12 default races and each of the races plays in a very unique way, yet the game keeps an asymmetric balance. Players are able to create custom races. Each phase of the game is different forcing you to change the way you play. Overall, war has a strategic facet that Civilization: Beyond Earth lacks.\n\nDownsides: The pirates are annoying and overpowered (You can turn them off). It is nearly impossible to achieve a diplomatic victory, making winning through diplomacy not an option. The combat system is too simplistic. Generally, whoever has stronger ships wins. The strategy aspect is reduced to a rock-paper-scissors style of choosing one of a limited number of tactics. It would be nearly perfect if it included a full RTS aspect like in Star Wars: Empire at War.

reviewText:
I want to love this game, I really do.  But I find myself hitting the next turn button more then making any active decisions.  It looks fantastic graphically and has one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard.  Many of the lessons from Master of Orion are on display here; leaders are great, lore is juicy.

But the battles are without any agency.  I pick a card and the computer picks a card at random and things happen.  Without any spying, your ships have to made in a vacuum (har, har) as to what you are going to face in combat.  I would just rather play the deeper MOO strategy then this beatific looking but hollow game.

7 out of 10; ~50 hours in.

I have higher hopes that ES2 will correct the depth problems and give us something more engaging.

reviewText:
From all 4X games that I have played, Endless Space captures the feel of ruling over a galactic empire best.
My favorite element of the game is how solar systems work as a whole, and with every system consisting of different numbers and types of planets, with different anomalies and wonders, gives every system you colonize some kind of 'character'. I love getting immersed in the feeling of space exploration and being challenged by every new system. You have to ponder 'Should I colonize this system right now, or wait until I've researched more terraforming technologies? Should I specialize it as an industry system, or use it for economy and research? Is building this huge, expensive improvement worth it, or should I stick to the smaller improvements in this system?'.

The other side of this feeling is that the things you do in this game are at the macro-strategy level. You don't build single buildings on planets, you build improvements for the whole solar system. You don't manage single trade routes, you build trade improvements in systems, and the trade routes will automatically connect your systems with those of other civilizations you are at peace with, in the most profitable way. You don't tell every single ship in a battle where to move, you set fleet formations at the beginning of a battle, and choose general strategies (Things like 'weapon overclock', 'camouflage', 'sabotage', 'repair', and many more) and aiming patters ('spread fire', 'concentrate on one enemy' etc.) for each battle phase (Long-Range, Medium Range, Melee Range), and aside from that, can't influence the course of battle.

Many players criticize this, but I have the impression that this is part of the narrative, and implementing micro-management options would rather hurt the game flow. In this game, you are responsible for the grand strategies, and this is reflected in the mechanics.

Other elements of this game that are important for my recommendation, personally:
- All of the factions are interesting and have a ship style that fits them well
- The music, made by FlyByNo, is magnificent! It enhances the game greatly.
- The User Interface is amazingly clear and elegant. With 4X games generally being complicated, this makes Endless Space significantly more beginner-friendly and comfortable to play.

reviewText:
TL;DR, a solid 4X with a couple unique & nifty features; lacks complexity, but it's at least not mind-numbingly easy. A solid intro to the genre on easier difficulties, and nice for veterans on hard+, definitely worth the price of admission for any fan of the genre...and at least worth a look if you're not, if you can snag it on discount.

With three games played and considering a fourth, something about it has me hooked, so I guess that's recommendation enough. This game is feature complete and isn't a platform for 4+ years of continuous overpriced DLC, so there's that too, I guess.

This game is the definition of what I think when I hear Civilization in space
date:
and is just about the same as Civ in how much of a repetitive slog to inevitable victory it is despite its shipbuilding & combat systems, and SUPERBLY crafted factions each with unique art/units/style, backstory, and game mechanics; I fell in love rather quickly. Sadly, as time went on and the veneer of starry-eyed wonder wore off, I discovered that the game ultimately lacks depth, as you end up rushing the same buildings & tech, and falling in line with the same battle strategies regardless of enemy or faction.

The Pros?

+ The Factions. As stated above, it's clear a lot of time was spent to make them all different, with detailed artwork & backstories, unique models for all faction ship classes, and game mechanics. I'm not just talking superficial changes in how they play, either: unique improvements, tech (and a mixup of where certain tech is in the tree), different specializations on your different ship classes, and a specific set of game rules - not just modifiers, but actual mechanics - endemic to each race that attempt to steer you into a particular playstyle with that race.

I mean, this alone makes me start up new games with factions I haven't played.

+ The shipbuilding, the real meat that sets Endless Space apart from many 4X games. The ability to personalize every part of your ships' systems and loadouts really adds a personal touch to your empire, and made me feel (rightly or wrongly) that any combat failures were my fault, that any overwhelming/surprising successes were my doing, and not some dickery of the game. There is no inevitability of overwhelming enemy numbers: as the supposed weakest" empire in my first game
recommended: my 9 little gunboats held the border against the entire enemy armada from the empire with more than double my score
hoursPlayed: simply by hardcountering its build.\n\n+ The aesthetics. The music definitely fits the whole "intergalactic space empire vying for supremacy" thing

I guess.

The Cons?

- You can - and eventually will - be dicked over by the galaxy generator. That's just the nature of the beast

reviewText: Do you like Civilization?  Do you like Space?  How bout Sci Fi?  If you answered yes then this game is for you!  A 4X game, basically its Civ in space.  You choose an alien race/faction (or create your own!) and then setup your game, dictating things like number of opponents, difficulty, and even style of the galaxy (a spiral?  a ring?  a big ellipse?)\n\nOnce you start play there is an awesome and super detailed tutorial that guides you through each screen and explains how the game functions.  You colonize star systems and then specific planets, and build a combination of planet specific and system specific upgrades.  You also build fleets of ships (from designs you create!) to do battle against space pirates and the other factions.  With multiple ways to win and everything being generated on the fly, this game is just pure awesome for strategy lovers.

reviewText:
Note:  This review was written for just the Emporer Edition of the game.  I have not yet tried it with the expansion.  If I ever get the expansion, I will update my review.

I felt conflicted about whether to recommend this game or not.  In the end, I decided that the pros outweigh the cons.  That being said, it has a lot of missed potential, and I hope they improve on a few things for the sequel.

Pros:
- The game is a lot of fun, especially beginning and mid game.  A lot of thought has been put into certain details, such as the tech tree, which makes it fun to explore all the different techs.
- You can customize your own race, and choose its advantages and disadvantages.  This, to me, is one of its strongest points.  I had a lot of fun creating my own alien races to play as and play against
- The game has an AI function that allows you to automate system management.  I didn't discover this feature until my 2nd playthrough, and let me tell you, it sped up the game a ton!  Now, you still need to keep tabs on what it is building and where, as the AI will not always make the choices that best suits your strategy, but for the most part it really speeds up the mid game.

Cons:
- The game as a steep learning curve.  The tutorial is more or less useless.  It took a lot of playing around with settings and features before I was able to figure out the ins and outs of the game.
- Ship combat is a little boring, albeit fun to watch at least.
- The End game leaves something to be desired.  Once you get past the mid game stage, the game tends to drag on.  This is especially true if you are trying to achieve different types of victories, such as the science or diplomatic.

In conclusion, This game is fun, but requires patience towards the end.  I hope that when they do the sequel, they tap into the potential that this game had.

6/10

reviewText:
Endless Space is a 4X game (expand/explore/exploit/exterminate) in the same vein as Civilization, with a lot of similarities to Civ IV. The game has a lot of interesting unique mechanics in addition to the normal Civ gameplay including a uniquely structured tech tree, purchasable heroes that can lead your troops or your planets, and a unique way to utilize your planets (cities essentially) for resources. In addition, the many traits that the different civilizations have change the dynamic of the game and your priorities. The ability to make custom civilations by mixing and matching these traits also gives a lot of room for creativity and new experiences.

However, the main flaw of Endless Space is that it feels somewhat lifeless. It does a lot of things well, but there isn't anything it does particularly amazingly. The game ends up feeling somewhat generic because despite the unique mechanics there isn't anything that stands out as a large improvement over other 4X games.

Overall I would recommend Endless Space to fans of 4X games, especially those that enjoyed CivIV more than CivV, and for people who enjoyed Endless Legend and want to try a similar game. However, for people who aren't huge fans of the genre I would recommend sticking to Civ or other common 4X games instead.

reviewText: Endless Space was the 4X stratergy game I spent years looking for.  I have spent so many hours playing Endless Space and telling myself Just one more turn..."\n\nThe procedural galaxies
date: stars and planets are wonderful.  The tech tree is deep and broad enough to make exploring it's extents.  Diplomacy and trade seems to work better than previous examples i've seen.   "Dust" as the answer to instant gratification works great and tales and remnants of  "The Endless" really add flavor to the universe
recommended:
even if they do ask more questions than they answer.

Having heros with buffs and nerfs that you can move around your empire to govern your worlds or command your fleets is nice.  I just wish they had a bit more charecter.  Some personality could be delivered by way of the occasional message to the player in the "voice" of the charecter via the game notice system.

reviewText:
I'm a big fan of this genre from Masters of Orion.   For an indie game this is pretty amazing.   If you are expecting pure combat, I don't think this game is for you.   It is more about system development and expansion.   I lost the first couple of games on weakest AI because I was focused on military.   I finally won a game on easy using Science.

Micro management of the systems.

This is actually very interesting.   I'm 40 hours in and I don't think I've mastered this at all.   My mid game, around 80 turns was very strong.  But my early game is still poor.   What is fun is to put the game in a window.  Then pull up dirty pleasure tv show off to the side and then just clicking through your planets to make them rapidly develop.   You actually have to read the system improvements because one size does NOT fit all.   In other words, on some systems it is a complete waste to build every improvement.

Tech Tree

Again another piece of the game that makes you think.   You don't need everything, especially if your are targeting a specific victory condition like dust, tech, aliance, etc.  Read and decide.  You must look at the planets near your home world before you unlock the colonization for those worlds.   Sure eventually you will get all but you need to race to unlock key strategic systems

Expansion

This is very cool.  It is easier to expand in sytems you own rather than sending out ships.  Makes sense right?   However you still need to send ships out to seed systems.  And you need to seed systems that either block other player's expansion or give you huge development potential.  And you haven't always developed the right technologies to seed the planets on the target system.  This makes for a great game play balance in the game.

Ship Upgrades

I really like the modification and retrofit system.  Very easy to use and key to keeping your fleet uptodate.

Combat

This is a bit dull but not the focus of the game.   You pick attitudes for three rounds of combats, long range, mid range, short range, then your ships do their thing.   I've found repairs to be pretty good.   But again I don't think the focus of the game on combat, especially since you only have about 5 classes of ships to fly with various mods on them.  It is easy to win other ways.

Diplomacy

I'm still a bit lost.   I don't quite understand why I can't initiate peace treaties.   Maybe that is the way amoeba's are.   Not sure.   Alliances seem good until you get thrown into a battle you don't want to be in.


Nay Sayers

It always reminds me of players that want to play the way they think rather than the way the game allows them to think.  Sure we all have had our frustrations with that.   Even I had that with the first couple of games.  But once you start looking for other ways to do things, the game opens up.

Value

I picked this up on steam sale.  Great value.   Fun little game completely worth the money.

reviewText:
This game is a ton of fun, I play this game with my friends.

Pro's
-Fully modable game, the games scripts can be modified with word pad so makes the modding side for scripts a bit nice and easy.

-Custom factions, you can design for custom factions by choosing the premade ship designs and a factiona ffinity really easy to do, the racial traits list is pretty big so you got plenty of choices.

-Easy multiplayer function, you can invite your friends right from steam, some times they need to be in the game already, normally happens if your game clients are havily modified.

-One of the few games that allows you to teraform your planets, and it is the only game that I have played that allows you to teraform your planets through multiple stages of teraforming.

-Huge Tech areas to have fun with, with special unique research for each racial affinity.

-The game is nice and complex so you can get your money's worth, via plenty of play time.

Con's
-If you end your turn as the enemy attacks you it can cause a game crash. (you can still load up from your auto save and then wait for the fight then continue after that)

-Visual bug, sometimes shows you having higher population slots on your planets then there actually is, then you move your mouse curser across the planet it will show the real slots.

reviewText:
A turn-based space 4x strategy game set on a grand scale of galactic proportions. Intended to be more of a sandbox start where the stage is set with back-story, races and factions, but it is up to you to define the story after that. While lacking some of the charm and character of a game like Civilization 5, where the characters were very immersive and the feeling of writing history compelled you on. Endless Space, while comparable to Civ 5 and other space strategy games, is not trying to be a copy but a beast of its own. The game also runs fairly well on machines built from crumpets, like mine, 100% 7 year old genuine golden machine right here.

The games strength lies in the screen you will be spending a lot of time with, getting to know, making tea for and so on; the galaxy view, also FIDS is a guy you will have to get friendly with, get to know FIDS real well – FIDS stands for Food, Industry, Dust and Science; optimizing these will be important. The interface on the default view and the leaves that stemming from the branches connected to the galaxy interface are simple and relatively easy to navigate; the economy is rather solid, with many resources to monopolize and exploit, – my favourites being Bluecap Mold and Hydromiel - with resources set on low it can create some interesting situations. Managing and growing your empire is can be done easily, but to keep an empire at its optimal level some loving care to keep it in check and sound engineering ideas  are required to achieve a lovely, green and flowering empire. You can also zoom in and out of the galaxy view and into systems which you will find at helpful and the planets vivid colours pleasing to the eye.

Hero’s can be important to your strategy too due to their boosting abilities and a variety of roles they can fill either in administration or fleet command, however they are not essential pieces to make keep your empire spinning – just be sure to pick them up and assign them to tasks if you can.

Expansion is a very good thing and is a big part of the games early stage. Systems contain planets usually of varying tiers with nice planets being tier one and smelly gas planets + floating rocks being the highest tier, needless to say tier ones are better. You should probably colonise lots of systems as quickly as possible... but not too many at a pace your empire cannot keep up with... that could end very badly and happiness will snowball out of control very quickly; also keep an eye on the happiness of the populous, try to avoid planets with really bad happiness modifiers early on unless you have a good reason to colonise that system – such as a good happiness modifiers outweighing the bad one or a burning desire for that system. Initially colonised systems become outposts and over time will become colonies, colonies are better in many ways, for one they have an influence ring which is good for you but bad for your enemies systems if it swallows it whole; during their outpost state they can still be attacked without war being declared so you might want to defend them from the unforgiving galaxy until they mature. Also be sure to have each system doing something, even if it’s just Industry to Dust conversion, wasted turns don’t come back.

Research, is a bit like a big expanding circle, you can plough through in one direction if you wanted to but before long you will have to turn back and follow up the other branches for important and relevant technologies; in game terms, N-Way Fusion Plants & Isolation Shields in the Applied Sciences tree is important early on while Applied Casmir Affect in the Exploration & Expansion tree is very good for early expansion, there are techs in the Diplomacy & Trading tree that is important to happiness and keeping yourself protected is always imperative to your survival so the Galactic Warfare tree will be visited regularly.

The somewhat unusual combat system has a somewhat offhanded approach to it. The cinematic battle sequences while pretty and enjoyable to watch lacks some of the interactivity people are used to, where normally you needed to rely on positioning and particular manoeuvres in battle; however instead you rely more on the way you have set up your fleet beforehand which is assisted by a cards which designate actions your fleet can perform, whether or not a heroic Admiral is in the fleet and fleet targeting options during the battle. These battles can be auto-resolved if you wish; you can also invade systems with a number of methods such as a general siege, bombing or sending in the troops – of course you can turn to place to ashes after if you wanted to. The battles are not grand and truly epic but are enjoyable and perform their role rather well. Ships are arranged into fleets, which can be managed from the fleet tab on the galaxy screen, are custom built from hull designs, while the general blueprints are not yours to play with, the toys you attach to it are. Good ship design is essential to defend yourself from hungry Cravers or invade some helpless Sophons on an isolated system; while some understanding of the combat system and understanding how to achieve your design goal is crucial for success, designing the ships in question is quite easy once you know where to find shipyard is.

Amplitude while being a small - French – studio, have put a lot of love into its first game, they have also allowed the community to get involved in a number of occasions to help make decisions for the future of the game through the Games2Gether system and forums and are updating the game regularly with content and fixes. Visit the Amplitude forums if you have any questions about Endless Space; discuss the game, query problems or related waffles on your mind. You can also check out their other upcoming* games Endless legend – another strategy game - and Dungeons of The Endless – a rouge-like-dungeon-delving game – if they snatch your interest and run of with it. So, lead your empire to victory in the deep darkness of space, through the vibrant jungles, across desolate barren landscapes, scorching hot sand dunes and towering metropolises. Explore, Expand, Exploit, Exterminate my good friend.

reviewText: Among the best in its genre, Endless Space does a beautiful job delivering a fun strategic turn based game.  Most comparable to civilization 5, or other turn based games, Endless Space has you slowly take turns improving your solar systems and taking over the galaxy.  You are given races, which enable the gameplay to change, not to mention the endless customization for creating your own race, and controlling the size of your galaxy.  On top of the 100+ hours you will satisfyingly get, there are also numerous achievements to work for if you want to get all the achievements.  One of the best games I have ever played, Endless Space is a must have for your game library.  This is one game where the developers listened, and they delivered.

reviewText: I haven't played since the Disharmony expansion came out, but this is a very nice 4X[en.wikipedia.org] game.  I rate it as the best space-themed 4X[en.wikipedia.org] game (of course, it's also among the newest) and second only to Sid Meier's Civilization games for best 4X[en.wikipedia.org] overall.  It would be tempting to call this Civ2 in Space, but that's not quite accurate.  Certainly, if you've played Civilization or any other 4X[en.wikipedia.org] game you'll recognize that the basic ideas and goals are the same - learning the /massive/ tech tree, manipulating heroes, and mastering the nuances of unit behavior will still take some time, however.  The interface is, unfortunately, clunky and hard to read in the same way that the old Civ games were.  The presentation problems are primarily related to the tiny fonts that don't seem to scale with screen resolution and the amazing complexity of the game.  Here, each hero has multiple disciplines with unique talent trees for each.  Deep options for ship customization almost make for a game within itself, as much time can be spent min/max optimizing weight budget by rotating out varying armaments, engines, colonization pods, hulls, and more.  Planetary systems are similarly complex, and require a fair amount of micromanagement for min/max players - it's a lot like the way it was necessary to position each villager for each town in old Civilization games at harder difficulties.  Unfortunately, it's also rather tedious.\n\nIf you're a fan of Civilization and the idea of Civ in space sounds enticing, then this is the game you should be looking at.  It's not perfect and the learning curve is substantial, but there's a lot of promise here.  I'm not sure if there is a follow-up in the works or not, but this is an amazing first effort and I can absolutely see the potential for successive versions to challenge Sid Meier's lordship over the 4X[en.wikipedia.org] genre.

reviewText: Its an indie 4X strategy game with the polish of Civ 5. Mechanics are deep, which allows for some nice strategies. Ship customisation is a blessing and a curse; It theoretically allows completely unique fleets, but falls short in balance. The rest of the game is very balanced however. Victory conditions don't feel very different from each other, but the AI is competent. reviewText:
It's okay.

The fleet vs fleet battle system is essentially a very enlarged game of rock-paper-scissors with three rounds and many cards that all counter each other differently, for a very complex and hard to predict web of cause and effect. It's incredibly satisfying when you pick the right card and blow your opponent to smithereens. Fleet size matters, but small fleets can beat larger fleets with good strategy, so it's well designed. In addition, the heroes you appoint have specialties and command the fleets, so it's all very satisfying to play fleet tactics.

Where the game falls behind a bit is in the overland starmap strategy. There are both size limits on fleets and movement/attack limits per turn on fleets, even if they are in the same system as an enemy. Logically, since the turns are a week, your fleet SHOULD be able to attack every enemy fleet in the system it's located in, but somehow it can only attack one, which is incredibly stupid because then the overland strategy becomes a tedious game of hide, seek, and run around repetitively.

The other way the game falls a bit behind is in fleet vs. planet combat. It's done only passively, and while the mechanics to decide it are sound enough, there's no interaction there, it's entirely automated. I don't understand why we couldn't have gotten an awesome tactical card game for planetary invasions too.

If you love political intrigue and economics, which I admit I also have a soft spot for, this game is not your thing. It's very polished, but not too deep beyond the fleet battles. It personally didn't work for me, not just because of the lack of depth beyond the combat but because of the strategic flaws. However, if you want a decent space 4x with a great battle system that doesn't take long to get in to, this is your game.

reviewText:
Cheating AI. Will cheat to counter action cards and regularly wreck otherwise logically winnable fights.
No skill involved in fights. Just ship numbers, technology and randomly getting cheated or not by the AI.

Cryptic research tree. At a glance, it's very difficult to understand what to research to achieve one desired effect.

Very, very bad UI with non draggable item frames (can only see 4 or so items from research, build, etc. and must scroll all the time), stupidly simple queues (can't drag / replace / relocate items due to circumstances) that force you to continuously reassign the build / research items.

Bad balance: regardless of race, be prepared for eternal war. there will always be someone who attacks you and attacks everybody else and just owns everything.

On the positive side, it's a classic space conquest turn based game a la Master of Orion. Lots of lore and accurate descriptions plus many possible improvements starmap side.

I completed one playthrough and a half, but will not play again because of the terrible shortcomings.
Purchase only if you really like the genre and don't mind a cheating AI even on normal and easy difficulty.

reviewText:
I'd never heard of this game before trying it out, but it turns out to be an excellent 4X TBS title.
This pretty much runs down the checklist of what I want in a game.  Variable alien races? check.  Expansive tech tree? check.  Randomized galaxy to explore, with good variety in system & planet types? check.  Combat is simple, but lets you have enough control?  check.
My only complaints are that some of the techs and upgrades seem way more useful than others, and one of the victory types feels a bit too easy to achieve compared to the others.  Also, the combat system can be a bit swingy, and the outcome of an engagement depends on factors that may not be obvious.  Lastly, combat and the other systems aren't explained all that well in-game, so you have to peruse the wiki to get a good idea of what's going on.
Still, I've sunk many hours into it, and have no problem suggesting it to others.

reviewText:
I actually got into this AFTER playing Endless Legend, and while I can see what lessons Amplitude took from ES and applied in EL, ES still gives an enjoyable experience for anyone looking for a Space 4X that isn't an RTS.

To put it short, the game is very administration and automation heavy. If you're the kind of person who likes the exploitation part of 4X, and if you like automating each of your turns to a science, then this is the game for you. I personally love making research decisions, setting waypoints for fleets, etc. and I can forgive the game's poor combat, but if you're looking for a game to stretch your strategic skills this isn't it.

I'm really enjoying this game. After Civilization V's expansion, Brave New World, Civ V became a bit biased towards smaller empires, so having a game that allows and repays rapid expansion and exploitation is welcome.

Despite the relatively small size of the playable maps, empires and armies can get pretty huge. The U.I. lacks character, but  it's really clean so administrating your empire is very easy. This is also one of the problems, though, as you start to get into the groove of running your empire every turn starts to feel monotonous, only broken up by random events that, more often than not, end up hurting your empire.

Battles are also not very strategic. The combat system is intriguing, but ultimately it just doesn't involve the player enough, and I hope in any future iterations of the game they use EL's battle system. Winning wars ultimately comes down to ship design (which you have to constantly evolve to keep up with your enemies) and outproducing your opponents. It feels really good to have twelve fleets going at once, though, and managing a large navy is also quite fun for me.

Great game if you like micromanaging your empire, maximizing production, science, and economic output and planning, then this is the game for you. Unfortunately, anyone looking for a strategic challenge should pass.

reviewText:
Note:  This review was written for just the Emporer Edition of the game.  I have not yet tried it with the expansion.  If I ever get the expansion, I will update my review.

I felt conflicted about whether to recommend this game or not.  In the end, I decided that the pros outweigh the cons.  That being said, it has a lot of missed potential, and I hope they improve on a few things for the sequel.

Pros:
- The game is a lot of fun, especially beginning and mid game.  A lot of thought has been put into certain details, such as the tech tree, which makes it fun to explore all the different techs.
- You can customize your own race, and choose its advantages and disadvantages.  This, to me, is one of its strongest points.  I had a lot of fun creating my own alien races to play as and play against
- The game has an AI function that allows you to automate system management.  I didn't discover this feature until my 2nd playthrough, and let me tell you, it sped up the game a ton!  Now, you still need to keep tabs on what it is building and where, as the AI will not always make the choices that best suits your strategy, but for the most part it really speeds up the mid game.

Cons:
- The game as a steep learning curve.  The tutorial is more or less useless.  It took a lot of playing around with settings and features before I was able to figure out the ins and outs of the game.
- Ship combat is a little boring, albeit fun to watch at least.
- The End game leaves something to be desired.  Once you get past the mid game stage, the game tends to drag on.  This is especially true if you are trying to achieve different types of victories, such as the science or diplomatic.

In conclusion, This game is fun, but requires patience towards the end.  I hope that when they do the sequel, they tap into the potential that this game had.

6/10

reviewText:
A turn-based space 4x strategy game set on a grand scale of galactic proportions. Intended to be more of a sandbox start where the stage is set with back-story, races and factions, but it is up to you to define the story after that. While lacking some of the charm and character of a game like Civilization 5, where the characters were very immersive and the feeling of writing history compelled you on. Endless Space, while comparable to Civ 5 and other space strategy games, is not trying to be a copy but a beast of its own. The game also runs fairly well on machines built from crumpets, like mine, 100% 7 year old genuine golden machine right here.

The games strength lies in the screen you will be spending a lot of time with, getting to know, making tea for and so on; the galaxy view, also FIDS is a guy you will have to get friendly with, get to know FIDS real well – FIDS stands for Food, Industry, Dust and Science; optimizing these will be important. The interface on the default view and the leaves that stemming from the branches connected to the galaxy interface are simple and relatively easy to navigate; the economy is rather solid, with many resources to monopolize and exploit, – my favourites being Bluecap Mold and Hydromiel - with resources set on low it can create some interesting situations. Managing and growing your empire is can be done easily, but to keep an empire at its optimal level some loving care to keep it in check and sound engineering ideas  are required to achieve a lovely, green and flowering empire. You can also zoom in and out of the galaxy view and into systems which you will find at helpful and the planets vivid colours pleasing to the eye.

Hero’s can be important to your strategy too due to their boosting abilities and a variety of roles they can fill either in administration or fleet command, however they are not essential pieces to make keep your empire spinning – just be sure to pick them up and assign them to tasks if you can.

Expansion is a very good thing and is a big part of the games early stage. Systems contain planets usually of varying tiers with nice planets being tier one and smelly gas planets + floating rocks being the highest tier, needless to say tier ones are better. You should probably colonise lots of systems as quickly as possible... but not too many at a pace your empire cannot keep up with... that could end very badly and happiness will snowball out of control very quickly; also keep an eye on the happiness of the populous, try to avoid planets with really bad happiness modifiers early on unless you have a good reason to colonise that system – such as a good happiness modifiers outweighing the bad one or a burning desire for that system. Initially colonised systems become outposts and over time will become colonies, colonies are better in many ways, for one they have an influence ring which is good for you but bad for your enemies systems if it swallows it whole; during their outpost state they can still be attacked without war being declared so you might want to defend them from the unforgiving galaxy until they mature. Also be sure to have each system doing something, even if it’s just Industry to Dust conversion, wasted turns don’t come back.

Research, is a bit like a big expanding circle, you can plough through in one direction if you wanted to but before long you will have to turn back and follow up the other branches for important and relevant technologies; in game terms, N-Way Fusion Plants & Isolation Shields in the Applied Sciences tree is important early on while Applied Casmir Affect in the Exploration & Expansion tree is very good for early expansion, there are techs in the Diplomacy & Trading tree that is important to happiness and keeping yourself protected is always imperative to your survival so the Galactic Warfare tree will be visited regularly.

The somewhat unusual combat system has a somewhat offhanded approach to it. The cinematic battle sequences while pretty and enjoyable to watch lacks some of the interactivity people are used to, where normally you needed to rely on positioning and particular manoeuvres in battle; however instead you rely more on the way you have set up your fleet beforehand which is assisted by a cards which designate actions your fleet can perform, whether or not a heroic Admiral is in the fleet and fleet targeting options during the battle. These battles can be auto-resolved if you wish; you can also invade systems with a number of methods such as a general siege, bombing or sending in the troops – of course you can turn to place to ashes after if you wanted to. The battles are not grand and truly epic but are enjoyable and perform their role rather well. Ships are arranged into fleets, which can be managed from the fleet tab on the galaxy screen, are custom built from hull designs, while the general blueprints are not yours to play with, the toys you attach to it are. Good ship design is essential to defend yourself from hungry Cravers or invade some helpless Sophons on an isolated system; while some understanding of the combat system and understanding how to achieve your design goal is crucial for success, designing the ships in question is quite easy once you know where to find shipyard is.

Amplitude while being a small - French – studio, have put a lot of love into its first game, they have also allowed the community to get involved in a number of occasions to help make decisions for the future of the game through the Games2Gether system and forums and are updating the game regularly with content and fixes. Visit the Amplitude forums if you have any questions about Endless Space; discuss the game, query problems or related waffles on your mind. You can also check out their other upcoming* games Endless legend – another strategy game - and Dungeons of The Endless – a rouge-like-dungeon-delving game – if they snatch your interest and run of with it. So, lead your empire to victory in the deep darkness of space, through the vibrant jungles, across desolate barren landscapes, scorching hot sand dunes and towering metropolises. Explore, Expand, Exploit, Exterminate my good friend.

reviewText: I haven't played since the Disharmony expansion came out, but this is a very nice 4X[en.wikipedia.org] game.  I rate it as the best space-themed 4X[en.wikipedia.org] game (of course, it's also among the newest) and second only to Sid Meier's Civilization games for best 4X[en.wikipedia.org] overall.  It would be tempting to call this Civ2 in Space, but that's not quite accurate.  Certainly, if you've played Civilization or any other 4X[en.wikipedia.org] game you'll recognize that the basic ideas and goals are the same - learning the /massive/ tech tree, manipulating heroes, and mastering the nuances of unit behavior will still take some time, however.  The interface is, unfortunately, clunky and hard to read in the same way that the old Civ games were.  The presentation problems are primarily related to the tiny fonts that don't seem to scale with screen resolution and the amazing complexity of the game.  Here, each hero has multiple disciplines with unique talent trees for each.  Deep options for ship customization almost make for a game within itself, as much time can be spent min/max optimizing weight budget by rotating out varying armaments, engines, colonization pods, hulls, and more.  Planetary systems are similarly complex, and require a fair amount of micromanagement for min/max players - it's a lot like the way it was necessary to position each villager for each town in old Civilization games at harder difficulties.  Unfortunately, it's also rather tedious.\n\nIf you're a fan of Civilization and the idea of Civ in space sounds enticing, then this is the game you should be looking at.  It's not perfect and the learning curve is substantial, but there's a lot of promise here.  I'm not sure if there is a follow-up in the works or not, but this is an amazing first effort and I can absolutely see the potential for successive versions to challenge Sid Meier's lordship over the 4X[en.wikipedia.org] genre.

reviewText:
Firstly, the surface stuff. the graphics and music are pretty good - the sounds are quiet and atmospheric like you would expect for the universe it's based in. The visuals are nice, and the manual battle sequences are pretty while most of your time is really spent in the battle map, where the UI, once you get used to it, works well enough. I find in a lot of these 4X type games, once you have a large amount of planets/cities/systems/whatever, it gets kind of tedious giving them orders every turn, but for the most part, come end game, you're either pumping out units or pushing for production to research or dust bonuses, so it's not that bad.

Now for story.  The factions all have stories and even intro videos that are actually interesting (the first time around). But don't get this game if you expect any kind of campaign because there is none - the story really ends at the beginning of a match. There isn't really much personality in the factions and how they act, it's more to do with some of the diplomatic factors you share with them. What is great though about factions is the multitude of customization traits. Each race has starting research and unique abilities and weakneses, and that you as someone who may want to make your own faction can try to balance yourself as you carve out their identity. Things like modifiers for diplomatic options, population growth, resource management, ship enchancements, etc.

Now the negative - taking a bad path in research can lead you down a disasterous path. There are things that are important to get and things that are only time sinks, and it is hard to know which is which when you're first starting out. The random nature of battles makes it kind of annoying at times - the only real strategy when it comes to battle is fleet composition and using certain modifiers at certain times, like boosts to armor or weapons power, but direct control over things is not something that is possible. The AI is a little dumb as well - early on, placing colonies at choke points is a way to box them in and sometimes they don't really do anything about it. Their minds change constantly about you, and alliances fall apart quickly or pop up out of nowhere because of something as miniscule as the fact that your colonies are neighbours.

But despite those points, I found the game quite enjoyable. The games take a long time, and there is a good amount of variety in customizing maps, so chances are you will get a fair amount of play time out of it. Basically, the more you play the more you will hone the route through the research tree and balancing all the other factors.

I'd recommend this game for sure, but say that the expansion really is something you should only get if you like the game yourself - the amount of content it adds is decent, but you will not make or break your initial impression by missing out on it (or getting it for that matter).

reviewText:
Endless Space is a turn based strategy game with a few good ideas but poor execution.

The number one gripe i have with endless space is the randomness of the combat.Combat involves picking cards to play during the  phases of combat,before the battle begins.You never know if the cards you picked will be countered or not by the Computer opponent. this means that even with a stronger fleet you can still lose a battle due to bad card choices.

Also laying seige to a planet takes far to long.Even with multiple seige vessels it can take upwards of 20 turns to conquer a single System!!!!

There is also little variation in the weaponry used by all factions.Though the ships from each faction look different,you will find yourself facing the same exact weaponry that your faction has researched.This causes stress beyong measure as you must constantly design new ships to counter the enemy factions vessel's,only to deploy those ships and find them countered by a new design from the enemy,forcing you back to the drawing board.

Overall there are simply to many great games similar to Endless Space that are less random,more in depth and simply more fun to play. Namely:Sins of a solar empire and Space empires gold edition.

reviewText:
The game's a basic 4x strategy game, its very pretty and has some nice soundtracks, the combats even more basic with linear upgrades for ships and a simple counter system but at least you get a pretty cinematic in the background.
Its quite buggy and playing online is almost impossible due to a myriad of bugs ESPECIALLY when using a large map.
If you see it going for cheap on sale I do recommend it if you like turned based 4x games.

Also if you can't stand seeing things that make absolutely no sense brace yourself if you do buy it because you may happen to see a giant tree sticking out of a gas giant at some point.

I am forced to not recommend it though due to the fact it hasn't got much substance beyond the pretty paint job, especially with regards to the derp AI and broken as all hell balance.

reviewText:
10/10

I recommend it.

Endless Space is everthing I could hope for in a game.  It gives me the freedom to customize my Faction as I wish, and to customize what kind of map I'll play on.  All of the factions are very unique and detailed, providing a lot of well written background from which to draw a strong narative from.  The hand drawn art mixed in with top notch graphics is an especially nice touch, and some of the faction art was so nice it graced my desktop background for a time.  To top it off, the gameplay, though perhaps not the best I've seen, was really well suited to this type of game.

All in all this was one of the few games that I thoroughly enjoyed playing, and my game time reflects this.

reviewText:
I really want to recommend this because I love like 90% of it; but it's absolutely ruined by the combat system. The combat system is awkward at best, and obtuse at worse.

There is also something off with the AI (I'm playing the latest version as of 1/2/2016). The AI is extremely aggressive, even at lower difficultly levels. It is just too aggressive and the worst part about this is I can't learn the obtuse combat system because of it.

Endless Legend is much better; just get that and play it. I respect this effort and look forward to Endless Space 2 but this either needs patches or it’s just not worth buying.

Should I notice a patch or update, I’ll try the game again and update this review as appropriate. But for now, no, I can’t recommend it and should you be inclined to buy it, get it on sale at least. I think you’ll get a few hours out of it but conclude something similar on the combat & AI. Again, love 90% of the game but those two things just make this not worth the time to play.

reviewText:
Endless Space is a great 4X strategy game (Explore, Expand, Exploit and Exterminate).

I mostly play action games and shooters and never played a 4X strategy game before. So my experience is extremely limited to say the least.

The only reason I got into this game is because of my love for the sci-fi. All those ships fighting in space looked very cool.

This game has a learning curve, and you might need to watch some videos on how to actually play it, what researches to complete and in what order, for example, this chick knows her shít:

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLcw-IheRx7UqeOZMTU6fdz-gU8APFeDAh

So after watching her videos I was able to win my first game on normal difficulty (which is definitely not easy).

Once you learn, it becomes very easy to understand what to do and when. It's just like in RTS games – you build armies and destroy opponent, only with more ways to win and everyone takes turns.

To sum everything up, it’s a very good entrance to a 4X strategy genre. At this stage, this game is fun, perfectly polished, fast paced for a TBS and relatively easy to understand. So I definitely recommend it to all sci-fi fans out there.

reviewText:
Note: I do not have the expansion pack, and cannot comment on how the game is with it.

Once you really understand how to use the diplomacy system, everything else is pointless when playing against the AI. If you don't understand why this is the case, then you don't really understand how to use the diplomacy system. Master it (which is really nothing more than learning a few tricks, albeit ones that many people inexplicably fail to discover) and even the -195 point race achievement becomes effortless, even boring.

Unfortunately, the game doesn't get much better even when playing stupidly (meaning not taking full advantage of the diplomacy system). Simplistic, counter-based ship design, similar to GalCiv2 (which suffers from many of the same problems), fails to provide much opportunity for meaningful tinkering, and the system of choosing a few tactics when going into battle is not an adequate substitute for actual tactical combat. I suppose that if you're super-interested in economic optimization, and aren't going to look too hard at the diplomacy system, you might find this game interesting.

Otherwise, you might want to look elsewhere.

reviewText:
Let's keep my review simple. I will assume you know what a 4X space game is about and just list how Endless Space fares in my opinion.

What Endless Space does really well:
- Impressive graphics
- Keeps micromanagement surprisingly low
- Balanced tech-tree
- Even with differences in research levels, battles are still not one-sided
- The KI opponents are quite capable diplomats. Where I usually NEVER accept an offer from KI-opponents in other games, the Endless Space" ones managed to "sell" me deals by offering the right incentives.

What it does okay (meaning it's nothing special):
- Several ways to win
- Different species and the option to create your own
- The KI opponents are quite good although they do get an unfair ingame advantage. I would prefer to be able to choose their difficulty AND the amount of "advantage" they get seperately.
- Diplomatic options have to be researched. While it does make for an interesting game mechanic I would still prefer to have all diplomatic options from the start.

What is missing:
- No espionage
recommended:
inciting rebellions etc.
- There is basically NOTHING besides the respective faction-intro to evoke some atmosphere in the game. Even when you finally win you only get a small picture of your faction and a rather neutral text telling you that you've just achieved economic / military / scientifiy victory.

Summary
All in all I would give it 4 out of 5 stars. It's very good and addictive but putting some atmosphere in there (voice-overs
hoursPlayed: a few animated messages etc.) would go a long way. Having some espionage and full access to diplomatic functions from the start would also help to make it even better."

reviewText:
Look... I dunno.  Is it fun? Yes.  Is it interesting?  To a point... yes.  Should you buy it when it's on sale?  Yes.

But...

There's this aspect of these kind of games that Civ5 has set the bar on... if yer gonna make a 4x game... that you HAVE to at least meet this bar.  If not, then yer just... I dunno... meh?  Polished, interesting and pretty meh... but meh none-the-less.

What bar?

Combat.  This game's combat is garbage... just... garbage.  Completely and totally garbage.  It is litterally the entire reason that I come back to this game over and over again and then a few hours into playing it I just get... meh.  It's fun and pretty and intricate, but the combat is just trash.

Sorry.  Play Sins of a Solar Empire.  Far far better.

reviewText:
I have semi jokingly renamed this game Endless Waste. Let me explain why.

Sure you have fleets in space check. You have planets you can build stuff on check. You can research technologies all check. What they don't tell you is there are plenty of 4x strategy games that accomplish these basics. The question is does this game accomplish it better? My answer is meh..... Yes, meh.......

Let me ellaborate. Many people complain of the card system for fleet battles in this game. By way of explanation before one of the three rounds starts you and the A.I must choose a card that fits your strategy. You have many options even starting off and more when you research them. How do they work in actual application? The difference is negligible really. Yeah the right card choice can make a tie a victory and the wrong card choice can make a tie a loss. What it can't do is make superior vessels lose. While i respect this choice for balance's sake it has one major drawback. Space conflict does not require much thought. Planning yes, thought no. TBH the disaster that was MOO3 is better in that sense but not graphically of course. The space battles do look nice.

Moving on to planets. Like i said yeah you can build on planets. The way they implement planetary research and production meh.... You can not have individual planetary production queues. I'd be fine with that if it were more like Galactic Civ 3 and you have the option of having a spacedock at every planet producing ships slowly or sending industry to one spacedock. This game does not have that option. Don't take me wrong I am not a Galactic Civ fanboy by any means. IMHO they are mediocre as well for one simple fact. The gaming experience does not evolve that much. Yet this game suffers from that sentiment even more.

Moving on to research. Yeah they have research. How do i rate it a tiny bit above meh.... to meeehhhh??.... While on paper the research ideas are good. The way the game implements them is very meh.... This is not the reaserch tree's fault though. It is the planet building and space combat's fault. Those systems make seeing tangible results not so immersive. Which is where Galactic Civ 3 shines and Endless Waste does not. Endless Waste is not very immersive. In Galciv 3 for instance it is surprisingly clear what effect the combat research has in combat. You can watch the missile hit and do damage to another ship. You see the ship catch on fire if it does not have enough Point Defense and the missile is strong enough. In Endless Waste you don't have that. Point defense don't launch lasers or countermeasures etc. Missile impacts don't leave clouds of debris and ships smoking and/or flaming. Making it feel like frankly not much is happening. It becomes quickly boring except through statistics... if you are a statistical person. The same with planetary infrastructure even though TBH the same can be said about that with majority of 4X strategy games including Galactic Civ 3. The major difference is with nothing truly immersive in Endless Waste you don't really feel compelled to keep playing. Your choices simply do not matter except through statistics. So in essence since neither planetray infrastructure or space combat is immersive how can research be immersive? The other two affect the one.

Leaving to one last consideration money. Is Endless Waste worth the money? To that I say depends. Let me elaborate. If you love statistics, if you love space and the concept of technologies, if you love that when on sale this is drastically cheaper than Galactic Civ 3 this is for you. For everyone else at most just like myself it's meh... at best.

In summary Endless Waste except for the select few is just that an Endless Waste of potential. If they only put in a tiny bit more effort this game would be playable for most of us. Right now not so much. It's too bad because i liked the concept.

reviewText:
I think it's pretty dry.

Until you research the technology for each interaction, there isn't much you can do with other species besides declare war. Battles look very impressive, but are extremely repetitive because of their format: 3 rounds in which you select bonuses to give to your ships and watch them duke it out. I found myself auto-completing battles before I finished my first campaign. Example: http://youtu.be/qusyxTgvtkM

There doesn't seem to be enough to do each turn and for a large part of each game, I find myself rapid-fire ending my turn.

The galaxy map/solar system map is very well designed and presents available information in fewer screens than any 4x game I've played.

reviewText:
Short version:
--If you're expecting Master of Orion 2, skip this title.  Ship designs and combat are lacking, and turns take too long.
--If you're expecting Sid Meier's Civilization: In Space, get this title.  There are more likenesses to Civilization than any other game I can think of.

Long version:
I put over 20 hours into this game, and played three games.  I picked it up after checking the resoundingly positive reviews, hoping it'd be something it wasn't.

PROS:
-A well made game.  This is not some Flash or iPhone game that got ported.  A lot of work and love was put into its creation.
-Diverse techtree and upgrade paths let you pick which way you want to develop.
-Multiple win conditions, (even though it eventually veers towards enemy battleships coming to take you down when the game tells on you for being close to victory)


CONS:
-Steep learning curve, laden with pages upon pages of text in tutorials that overwhelm the new player with information they are unlikely to remember or make use of when it is explained.
-Game prone to freezes and crashes.
-Game ends before you're ready.  Oh

reviewText:
Too Complicated For My Liking, Steep Learning Curve
I'm going to start off by saying this is not a review. This Is a suggestion that you try to find a demo or some way to play the game before you buy it. I have not played this game nearly enough to review it, This could be a really good game, There are certainly solid design ideas and game mechanics but... I'm really doubting that I'll be able to get into it.

Allow me to explain. In a game like civ 5, my experience has been that while there is strategic depth to be had, its not forced on you. I was able to pick up the concepts of civ 5 fairly quick, and I didn't have the feeling that I needed to understand everything to play the game. This game was precisely the opposite.

I was so completely overwhelmed in the tutorial by the sheer number of screens, boxes, information tabs, icons, phases, etc, that I quit the game out of frustration because I felt like I was retaining almost none of the information dumped upon me. Add to that the fact that almost every tab background was the same semi-transparent grey box making them all look fairly similar and the unnessary complication of the  renaming of game concepts like money and resources to things like dust" and "FIDS"
date: and it's pretty clear to me that there were plenty of things that could have been made so much simpler without any real loss in depth.\n\nTo fans of the game
recommended: Please don't misunderstand me. I'm sure its a terrific game. I wanted to enjoy it as much as anyone else
hoursPlayed: but I have neither an extraordinary amount of patience nor a fantastic memory
voteText: and I feel like one of those things is required to enjoy this game."

reviewText:
Fun for 10 hours.

Buggy and AI loops creating a milking scenarios. Was winning a game on hard until AI started running fleets into one of my systems. They'd attack and immediately retreat, exausting my fleets moves. Was unable to attack them on the retreat. This meant they could sit siege weapons on the system unharmed; unable to attack them, unable to attack any other fleets.

Cynamitics were cool at first. Until you figure out it's the same sequence every time.

Ship building is fun in the beginning. But you start to realise how limited your options are. There are only 2 kinds of ships in the end; war ships and siege ships. You can't diversify your war ships because you can't choose who's on the front-line in space. Meaning, the only diversity you'l have in your fleet is between your upgraded units and your older units. Medium range and short range weapons are worthless so load up on medium and short range defense and stack long range attack.

The game feels a little spread thin. What is there is good but after 10 hours you feel like you've seen it all.

In summary: Very fun in the beginning but eventually loses it's charm. Good buy on a steam 80% off deal but don't buy at full price. With that said, Ill probably play another 5 hours of this.

reviewText:
If you want Civ 4 in space, buy it. Otherwise don't bother.

Graphics are nice but barely ever seen.

90% of the game is administration of dots with lines in between them whether it's the map screen and the dots are solar systems or the solar system map and the dots are planets or the research screen and the dots are technologies urgh.

Large games get slow super fast - not graphically but logistically - as the AI and yourself begins to do more. Late game combat is huge numbers of ships divided into fleets of limited size all attacking each other one by one to see who wins (just like Civ 4).

That said if you like Civ 4 and don't mind the lategame grind (unless you rush culture etc) and the fact that the combat in this is about as interactive as the combat in Civ 4 (Attack this - oh ♥♥♥♥ you're dead. Lets hope one of the 19 other units just like you eventually wins) then you'll get along well with this.

So reccomended just be warned. The pretty screenshots are less than 10% of the game. Most of it is admin. Admin with a good soundtrack, interesting lore, nicely balanced but feeling difference races and racial ships etc.

reviewText:
I absolutely love this game! Though it holds some similarities with Spore and the Harmony faction reminds me of the crystal species from Stargate SG-1. If you have a lot of time on your hands or enjoy games that take a long time then this is the game for you.

A nice turn based strategy game that gives you a 4 branched skill tree, with every species having their own special skills. Maps can be tiny to huge! I love that you can pick  the type of galaxy you play in and being able to make your own faction. Ship building is very complex though you cant actually design a ship but you can add or remove components to change the function of a ship.

Space battles are, in my opinion, really awesome! At the beginning of the encounter you pick a counter measure for each of the 3 phases and then either click Automatic or Manual. Automatic does a quick battle showing health bars and what not. Manual on the other hand goes through a cinematic of the attacking fleet coming out of warp near the defending fleet, and then the battle begins. Some counter measures will cancel the other fleets out and some will allow both to be used.

Depending on your faction you have to keep your populations happy or they will go on strike. Many factors such as anomolies on planets, overpopulation, and expanding too fast through out the galaxy all play apart in population happiness.  You can terraform planets to your needs and discover ancient technologies made by the mysterious Endless.

reviewText: This game is a fantastic space alternative to Civ V. I personally love Civ V but just became bored of it after a while because I felt it was too cluttered and it really annoyed me for some reason. Endless Space has so much to offer but at the same time the UI is one of cleanest I have ever used. It is fairly simple to get into as I felt I knew the mechanics very well after just a few hours of playing the game. Also, the graphics are extraordinary in my opinion. I don't feel like any of the battles could graphically be any more polished (besides some variation in ship positions, which would make them feel less repetitive). Overall I strongly reccommend this game and I think you are a fool to not buy it at its current sale price ($7.49). If strategy games are one of your favorite genres, I can guarantee you will enjoy this one!

reviewText:
This game provides hours of fun. It doesn't matter if you already are familiar with 4Xish space strategy games or not. For those old master of orion veterans, there is much to love and to complain about which will keep you testing and enjoying for weeks. Coming to this kind of gameplay newly, this is the best introduce you might get. For me everything what might be boring about this genre is tweaked so nicely. Every game start feels promising and encouraging. The turn based concept makes it perfect for chilled gaming sessions alone.

pros:
- lore and story, for me as a fan of scifi: everything fits fine and interacts well with the different races/backgrounds
- intuitive user interface (for real maybe the best thing 4x-turn-based experienced the last 10 years)
- ship builder
- easy to track influences on game mechanics - and thus favourable to learn and understand the game
- extends the classic gameplay slightly but all so impactful
- leaves out overaged mechanics
- game price

cons:
- turn based, games with extended turn number will take for ever, not recommended for multiplayer, but it never was with this kind of games
- fighting can be disappointing, because influences are not that clear and heroes overwhelm any strategy choices

reviewText:
This is a great 4x game with amazing visuals. It has a unique and simple battle system so anybody new to 4x games will know what to do.

Every game you start feels different from the last one, even if you keep to the same setup. Also there is no solid learning curve as there are many possibilities and out comes. Even if you do come across a situation that feels familiar the out come and your position with in the game may lead you down a completely different path than the one you were expecting. This makes every game you play highly unpredictable.
The game can be quite difficult and frustrating for beginners, even on easy. The level of weapons tech of your enemies very quickly matches yours if you do not invest in your own weapons technologies during a conflict. This makes the game challenging on every level.
After long play the game can get repetitive. Dealing with all your planets on each turn can get complicated and frustrating. You can save on any turn.

The game graphics are stunning. The level of detail they have put in, on the planets, the galaxy and the battle scenes are amazing. You can tell they have taken there time to get this game looking good.

The sound effects are not quite in the same power of the graphic. However they are simple and effective for this type of game. The sound track is very good and sets the tone of the game well.

The controls work very well. You can operate most of the game with just a click of a mouse. You do have the option to name planets and ships which obviously requires a keyboard.

I do recommend this game for the amount of detail they have put in to the graphics, storyline and descriptions of technologies. However some players may find it difficult and also after long play you may find it repetitive and frustrating.
