reviewText:
Endless Space is quite a fun game too play. If you expect the depth of a Civilisation title you'll better don't get it. But is has some of it within. There is a great tech tree, some neat mechanics and a great Ship Modification System. Playtime of a full set of course depends on how many enemies and which difficulty you choose.

I really, really like to give some big props to the Developers, because it's beautifully designed and nice and clean to play. These things really make me want to check out the Endless Dungeons Title from them.

So in conclusion; In case you search some turnbased strategy in space and you don't want to get all too deep into the Civilisations thing - get it. The first 30min are preserved to get into the game, but I'm sure almost everyone will actually get into it after these minutes of training. Speaking of training, there is only a textbased Tutorial which covers about 85% of the mechanics basics. But, for me, it was enought to figure out the rest of the gameplay.

What is sad, is that the multiplayer (at least the public one) is almost dead. About 2 to max. 3 Games are going on, whenever I log in. So you'd better pick your friends and start a nice game. :)

reviewText: I'm not sure if I am using the phrase 'Indie sleeper hit' correctly, but I do not care. This is in my top 5 games of 2012, and is probably one of my favorites of all time. It combines elements of civilization and Galactic civilizations into one neatly packaged, entertaining game. Those who are not fans of comparatively slow paced strategy games may feel the length of turns at times, but the feeling of reward turn after turn is rewarding. The combat is unique for it's kind, if not intuitive. It can add lengths to turns, but that is it's only detriment. The custom faction bit adds a lot of replayability after you get comfortable with the game, and I have barely touched the online scene. All in all, if you like strategy games, space sims, or any combination of the forementioned games, I HIGHLY reccomend this. The only thing that I can gripe about is it's unforgiving difficulty, and complexity of research. I give this 9 out of 10 corborbs.

reviewText: A fun strategy game, akin to Space Empires or Civilization in space. In other words it is not a game focused mainly on the action or combat, the fun comes in managing and upgrading your empire and ships. The combat itself is interesting, you don't control the ships directly but rather issue up to 3 commands using command cards. You do get to customize and name your own ship builds, and there are 4 huge branches of research to explore. The graphics and UI are nice as well.

reviewText: Endless Space is to the 4X space strategy genre what Civilization is to real time strategy games. An extensive tech tree and custom ship designs leave lots of room for variety, and as the game progresses these factors force changes in tactics to keep players on their toes. The expansion and colonisation system is remarkably good, and even with dozens of worlds to manage the beautifully simple UI ensures it is never a chore. Combat may not be to the taste of everyone, however. A very hands off affair, the player chooses cards to establish their tactics in a three-turn battle, and then it plays out itself. For those who love real-time battles this could be a turn off, for those of us who prefer combat to be less of a distraction it''s a godsend. For me personally, Endless Space has rendered all other 4X games obsolete.

reviewText: Nice game. Complex, but not that hard-to-master 4X turn-based game like I was expecting for quite some time. The AI is quite challenging, even if plagued with some consistent bug (they still keep invading systems without siege power, AFAIK), and there's a really excellent interface that allows you to quickly manage even a vast space empire. Space combat is quite basic, and very different if compared to Master of Orion 2 (if you don't know what I'm talking about, consider it as the current standard for this kind of games): no more ship direct controlo nor tactical combat, simply choose your tactics and watch the video.\nThis is NOT necessarily bad, mind you: it's a game more focused on strategic empire management than ship micromanagement, and it's quite great at it. Still, you can't shrug off the feeling that MoO2 was more complete and immersive, and that's a shame because ES had every card to strip Master of Orion of his crown.

reviewText: Endless Space is definitely the game for people to who love to micro-manage and then see their efforts pay off. I like to compare it as Sid Meier's Civilization after you win a scientific victory by going to space. It has an amazing technology tree system, a fascinating diplomacy interface, and extensive options to customize battle. My friends and I have gotten countless hours of fun out of playing it, and the AI is challenging enough to keep you occupied for weeks. I would defiantly recommend it and hope you get as much enjoyment out of it as I have had.

reviewText: I'm usually not a huge fan of strategy games, I have played my share of Civilization over the years, but overall, the genre is not my kind, but I gotta say Endless Space has something special going on, it's pretty fun and extremely addictive, be ready to spend hours playing turn after turn as you unravel your master plan of galactic domination. Each faction has a different style of gameplay and the change from one to another is quite significative, so you'll need to take plenty of factors in consideration as you determine how you will advance. reviewText:
Speaking as a former gaming journalist and gamer who's had MOO2 installed on every PC he's ever owned since it was published, I don't think people have been fair to this game. It's belongs in the 8s, not the 7s, IMO.

As many have said. It's pretty.

Something not many have said is that the UI is uncharacteristically strong for the genre, which is something I especially appreciate now that I write UI rather than game reviews for a living.

Most importantly, it scratches the MOO itch like nothing else has for me to date . I tried but could never really get into Gal Civ. SoTs was heaps of fun while it lasted but not really a similar enough experience to satisfy the same cravings. More than any other 4X sci-fi game I've played to date, Endless comes closest to the MOO2 experience not because it's trying too hard  as a me-too game, but because deep in the roots of Endless's game design, you can see that its designers really understand a lot of the critical aspects of what made that game fun (and even some of the things it could have done better).

There's definitely some stuff that I wish was different of course.

For instance, the best terraforming tech is way too far up the tech tree. By the time you've come close to perfecting all of your worlds, the AI will be threatening to clobber you with one of many non-eXterminating victories if you haven't all but stomped it into near oblivion at that point. Enjoying the role of magitech one-climate-world planetologist as much as I have in many games over the years, it bummed me out a little but I haven't tried fiddling with the settings that slow the game's pace down yet.

To be fair, however, there's plenty of planet-tinkering to be done and the game takes the stances that there really should be no useless planets. Asteroids bring unique system improvement opportunities. A certain hero gives insanely beefy boosts to gas giants which give the strongest resource boosts per colonist but to a high degree of specialty and with a very low max pop. Barren and volcano worlds suck for the reasons they typically do but can actually boost their specialty resource production higher than more ideal equivalents once a given system can afford the unhappy colonist hit.

For the most part, upgrades are system-wide (which makes high world count systems extremely desirable since most resource-boosting improvements are per-colonist) but each planet can also have an exploitation" built for it which essentially gives an added boost in one of the resource types with additional boosts for specific planet types.

Resource balancing is pretty unobtrusive. If one of the four resource units isn't in enough supply you'll notice in the form of things not happening as fast as you would like them to rather than disaster. No food means zero pop growth
recommended: for instance. I'm a little dizzy at times so I appreciate this. I also like that the game won't let you end a turn without research selected as there are a ton of topics and research can move pretty fast.\n\nHappiness is the thing you have to really think about or risk being punished for it. Colonists dislike excessive expansion. They can actually get grumpy at you for overpopulation and excessive expansion at the same time (uncanny realism for the human-originating factions
hoursPlayed: IMO). This effectively eliminates colony-spamming as the one-true-colonizing strategy
voteText: making it better to focus not just on quality systems at first but on where you're colonizing them due to the game's zone of influence mechanic
helpfulPercent: which is basically a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥-on/flag-planting mechanic where colonies sprout faction territory zones after (arbitrary perhaps
votesHelpful: but it works) 30 turns. Zones grow and push each other and you can't colonize inside another faction's  zone
votesTotal: which forces a lot of interesting strategic decisions and requires thinking about colonization rather than Zerging it.\n\nI actually like the AI for the most part. The only thing I'm still on the fence about is the fact that a faction will sometimes go to war on you because your score is getting too high. I kind of wish I could turn that off because that makes the AI opponents feel more like simulations of not-very-smart human opponents than simulations of other alien factions but that brings me to a point I really love about the AI. I know that the AI declared war on me for that reason because THE GAME TOLD ME. It's possible the AI will go to war on you for stupid reasons
votesFunny:
but never for "no reason" as the most helpful review to date reports. The game tells you why the AI did what it did. All you have to do is read the event report and it usually makes sense.

The other thing that's fun about the AI is that it isn't stingey and it knows when to quit.  When an AI faction declares war on you and you immediately start gobbling up its colonies like popcorn it will offer you several systems to get you to stop in the hastily offered surrender agreement. It's a nice change from those cheap ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s trying to hock their antimissile rockets for your Xentronium armor for the 20th time in a game or having to conquer 3/4 of their entire empire before they'll even consider peace.

It's still terribly stupid when it comes to evaluating circumstances like the fact that every ship in your considerably smaller armada has 4 layers of kinetic shielding and beam weapons and every ship in its fleets has kinetic weapons and zero beam shielding but I wouldn't have it any other way. Punishing that kind of stupid is fun.

Combat and ship design were satisfying enough for me
commentsCount: but could use more nuance and there's essentially no tactics. There are three weapon types that each work best at a certain range/phase of battle. Each has a counter defense. Weapons and defenses can be added in quantity at their respective hardpoints. There are a variety of support and special modules but most serve to add fixed modifiers to that essential formula (fighters and bombers being an exception). So design is really around offense vs. the defense and what the AI is likely to be fielding (hint: mostly kinetic in the early game).\n\nFights consist of setting targeting priorities and special power cards to play for three phases/ranges of battles that can cancel other player's cards out if they're of the right category and then hitting "manual" to watch the fight play it or "auto" if you feel safe not watching a different algorithm sort the battle out
column16: potentially killing ships that would otherwise be nigh impregnable in a watched battle.\n\nAs I said
column17: satisfying enough and I like the cards better in practice than I did on paper. Hero levelling and tech unlock fairly interesting ones and they won't overturn a major disadvantage. But I prefer gadgets and a wide variety of weaponry with quirks and unique behavior within a given type. There's no clever gyro-destabilizer/tractor beam combos to be had here and absolutely no thought to be put into whether you want the next level of kinetic
column18: beam
column19: or missile weapon because it's just bettter and there's really only one upgrade path for each. I definitely hope we get something more tactical and varied if there's an ES2 as this is one of the few spots I felt the game overstreamlined things.\n\nOne thing that impressed me on the other hand is the way they handled custom factions. ES has MOO's faction detailed individuality cake (granular stuff like research specialties and other races they liked/hated) and eats MOO2's customization too by giving each of the established factions a faction affinity that's a sort of template of specialized abilities
column20: tech tree options and diplomatic dispositions that are decoupled from a fairly detailed point-buy system and whatever appearance you choose.\n\nAny criticism aside
column21: this game is a very solid addition to the genre with a lot of good ideas. It may not have the 1000+ hours longevity like MOO2 has had for me but it might have MOO1's and I fully expect to get a lot of play out of it."

reviewText:
Let me be clear, know what your buying before you purchase this game. I bought this game durring the holidays sales expecting something along the lines of civilization. Which is partialy true. To that I must say, if you long to play civilization play civilization. This game is by no means bad, but when held up against Triple A titles like the Civilization franchise it leaves much to be desired. Every time I play this game I don't last long knowing I could just as easily be playing Civilization V with a few brief mouse clicks.
The combat is oddly enjoyable to watch, but more or less comes down to a complicated game of rock paper sissors in which the person with the most units wins (most of the time). Some aspects of the planetary leveling system seem overly complex, and I found little challenge with the games AI.

However, something draws me to this game. If you like turn based tactics, and strategy, or world building sims like the Civilization franchise, and if you are a fan of sci fi that longs to spread your cultural ideals... or your love space debries and burning plasma then this game may be for you.

IF your a fan of Sci Fi and are familure to the Empire building genre it's worth a look
But if your looking for the next evolution in Empire building strategy, you may want to pass this game over
All in all I still recommed this game, it's nothing compared to its Big Brother Civilization, but it has it's own charm and atmosphere which I personaly enjoyed. And if you can catch a steam sale, it's a good buy

reviewText: It takes time, it takes patience, and it takes a willingness to lose. But if you put these 3 key ingrediants into this game it'll start to connect. Aside from very silly game bugs (like having a just-captured system take only one turn to reconquer on either side), there isn't much to complain about. Expect to be a little flustered however, because this game has an intricate tech tree and unique game mechanics. These will leave in the dust a little bit, so start your first game on an easier game setting. But aside from that, this game offers an enriching strategical environment in which you can truly show your guff and mettle on an interstellar level.

reviewText: It takes time, it takes patience, and it takes a willingness to lose. But if you put these 3 key ingrediants into this game it'll start to connect. Aside from very silly game bugs (like having a just-captured system take only one turn to reconquer on either side), there isn't much to complain about. Expect to be a little flustered however, because this game has an intricate tech tree and unique game mechanics. These will leave in the dust a little bit, so start your first game on an easier game setting. But aside from that, this game offers an enriching strategical environment in which you can truly show your guff and mettle on an interstellar level.

reviewText: A turn-based Galactic Conquest strategy game with diplomacy, research, custom ship design, custom faction design, lasers, explosions and a race of mechanical locusts. One of the best strategy games I've ever played, though I can only recommend this with the Disharmony DLC, as that adds in fighters, bombers, massive UI changes and overall polish, mostly to weapons and invasions.

reviewText: This game, this game. Probably has one of the better tech trees and economies I've seen in a 4X game. Extremely solid on both sides that keeps you guessing pretty handily. The combat is insanely beautiful, but gets rather...stale early on and the campaign map, if you will, is sparse and extremely disappointing. No ability to see the planets, and everything is basically a circle with a line to each other really took it down a notch for me. The differing races and how they effect the map is very well done, so I would recommend this game to those who aren't too choosy on presentation of a map and care more about balancing economy/pretty combat.

reviewText:
Being a decades-long veteran of space empire-building games, and having followed and supported the development of this game since beta, I can honestly say that I am fairly well-acquainted with the goals and motivations that drove Endless Space to be what it has become. While it definitely follows in the footsteps of many of the games that have preceded it in its genre, the developers at Amplitude have succeeded quite well in creating a unique game with its own vision and theme.

At a basic level, Endless Space takes inspiration from classic games like Master of Orion, Stars! and Spaceward Ho! The interfaces are clean, simple, and intuitive, controls are easy and responsive to use and useful information that the player requires to make good decisions is presented in a straightforward and organized manner. Easily navigable menus, well-labeled buttons and a handful of sliders ensure that any function or command is no more than two or three clicks away at all times. Empire management, ship design, diplomacy, and research all blend seamlessly together, enabling a player to manage even a fairly large empire relatively quickly, keeping turns short and the game moving at a solid pace.

While Endless Space does contain all of the standard space empire-builder conventions, they are generally presented in a very flavorful way. Like Master of Orion and its sequel, Endless Space has a rich and lore-heavy backstory behind it; the difference is that this lore permeates the gameplay itself in a much more extensive way. It also takes a page from the Civ series of games by introducing strategic resources that can provide bonuses to players that control them, as well as limiting the availability of certain technologies by requiring them as prerequisites for ship components and even some facilities. Many planets possess unique features, of which there are many, which will provide specific bonuses (or penalties) depending on the technology the player has at hand.

Ship design is easy but broad in scope; there are six different size classes for hulls, each of which is better suited to fulfilling certain roles. Even the largest hulls cannot hope to carry much of everything, forcing you to design specialized vessels and build mixed fleets to deal with specific scenarios. Space combat is a real-time, strategic experience that rewards good planning and recon, rather than reflexes. Much like in GalCiv2, starship weapons and defenses utilize a rock/paper/scissors approach; care must be taken to balance your ships to match an enemy's strengths and exploit their weaknesses. Each weapon type has a specific range where it is the most effective, and specific tactics must be chosen to maximize the effectiveness of weapons fire as well as counter the enemy's plans.

Diplomacy is not given short shrift, either; a detailed counter keeps a record of all the different factors influencing your relationship with the other factions and gives you a comprehensive breakdown of why they like (or hate) you. There are extensive options for signing agreements and making trades, as well as a number of potential relationship states, and access to all of these depends on how many xenocultural techs you have researched as well. (The only weakness in this area is the lack of a detailed espionage system). The tech tree itself is extensive and provides a wealth of options depending on your preferred playstyle, with several of the victory conditions tied directly to tech tree items

The game has changed considerably in the time since it was first released; the developers have shown great interaction with the community and have responded directly to player feedback in shaping the content provided by each new update. Players who have bought the game and joined the community gained the ability to cast votes for what they prefer to see next; we have seen the inclusion of entire new races, an updated tech tree with more race-specific techs, an overhaul to the ship design system, the addition of strike craft and improved invasion and siege mechanics, and exploration-related random events. Planetary wonders, unique planets, and an array of powerful leaders who can be hired and gain experience levels from governing planets or leading fleets add a deep level of strategy. Add all of this to a wealth of options when setting up a new game, and Endless Space allows for literally 'endless' replayability for hundreds (if not thousands) of hours of deep strategic gameplay.

reviewText:
EDITED: Since installing dishonored, the game no longer starts. Might be something to do with all the updates, but have tried all the usual forums and fixes and nothing. So dissapointed, and as usual can't get my money back.

ORIGINAL: This game is too hard. Regardless of settings, unless you're a master strategist and/or know strategy games inside out, you just can't beat it. It's really annoying, because i really like what this game offers i.e. good gameplay at the start, nice 3d environment and solar systems, ship design, tech research etc.... but then it spoils it when you're nice little growing solar systems are overrun with enemies every time. Yes i get that it's seemingly a more serious game than most strategy games (which it doesn't really communicate in the listing), but when i pay ~£20 for a game i want to be able to at least use one mode of that normal folk can use.

Other than the difficulty issue, its a really good game.
